TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was born on DATE in GPE and has NORP nationality . He came to GPE in DATE and lived there continuously until his deportation . His parents and his CARDINAL brothers and sisters reside in GPE . CARDINAL of his brothers and sisters were born there . He claims that he lived with a woman of NORP nationality ( Miss PERSON ) , whose child , born on DATE , he formally recognised on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant was convicted on a number of occasions . On DATE he was sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , CARDINAL of which were suspended , for burglary . On DATE he was sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment for an assault resulting in the victim ’s not being fit for work for DATE . On DATE he was fined MONEY for driving without a licence and without insurance and on DATE he was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for living on the earnings of prostitution with aggravating circumstances .

Whereas PERSON ... committed the followingoffences : on CARDINAL DATE a burglary ; onCARDINAL DATE an assault on the person of arepresentative of the public authority who was performinghis duties ; on DATE an assault ; and from CARDINAL DATE to DATE , acts amounting toliving on the earnings of prostitution with aggravating circumstances ;

CARDINAL . ORG The deportation order was executed on CARDINAL DATE but the applicant returned to GPE and lived there illegally .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal alleging that the deportation order was an abuse of authority .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant applied to the Minister of the Interior to have the deportation order rescinded . His application was rejected on CARDINAL DATE on the following grounds :

I hereby inform you that the deportation order was madeby the competent authorities in view of the nature andincreasing gravity of the offences committed by theapplicant . The threat to public order was also assessedwith reference to Mr GPE ’s general conduct as wasrequired under the circular on the implementation of theLaw of CARDINAL September CARDINAL .
In addition , ORG ] confirmed the deportation order on DATE .
It is accordingly impossible for me to grant your request . The deportation order of DATE must therefore remain in force .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE Mr Boughanemi lodged with ORG an application for judicial review of the Minister ’s decision refusing to rescind the deportation order . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE dismissing the application , the PERSON court gave the following grounds :

Under section CARDINAL of the Ordinance of DATE , asamended in particular by GPE DATE to the provisions of LAW maybe decided by order of the Minister of the ORG if analien ’s presence on NORP territory constitutes aserious threat to public order . The deportation ordermay be rescinded at any time by the Minister of theInterior ... ’ Although section CARDINAL , as amended by theaforementioned PERSON , prohibits the Minister , save in casesof extreme urgency as provided for in section CARDINAL , fromordering the deportation of certain categories of alien , that provision can not be usefully invoked to support anapplication to have a previously issued deportation orderrescinded . It is exclusively a matter for the PERSON whom such an application has been made to assesspursuant to LAW whether the presence of the personconcerned on NORP territory constitutes at the date onwhich he gives his decision a serious threat to public order .

In the first place , it follows from the foregoing thatthe submission based on the fact that Mr Boughanemi haslived continuously in GPE since DATE and thatfor that reason , in accordance with the new section CARDINAL ofthe Ordinance of DATE , a deportation ordercould not be made against him after the coming intooperation of the PERSON of DATE is without force inregard to the decision refusing to rescind thedeportation order made against him on DATE . PERSON he rely on the principle that more lenient criminallegislation should be applied with retrospective effect .

Secondly , an appeal brought against the deportationdecision of CARDINAL DATE alleging that it was an abuse ofauthority was dismissed as unfounded by a judgment ofthis court on DATE . That decision carries withit the authority of res judicata , which precludesMr Boughanemi from pleading the unlawfulness of thatmeasure in support of his submissions directed againstthe refusal to rescind it .

Finally , the documents in the file show that theMinister , who took his decision in the light of all thecircumstances of the case , did not make a manifest errorof assessment in concluding , on the basis of the actsthat gave rise to the applicant ’s being arrested andprosecuted on several occasions DATE andaspects of PERSON conduct , that the latter’spresence on NORP territory constituted a serious threatto public order and in refusing on those grounds torescind the deportation order made against him .

It follows from all the foregoing considerations that the applicant ’s submission that the impugned decision isvitiated as an abuse of authority is unfounded and hisapplication to have it set aside on that ground must fail . "
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the ORG d’Etat dismissed the applicant ’s appeal lodged on DATE . It gave , inter alia , the following reasons :

Although the wording of LAW of the above - mentioned LAW of DATE was amended by the PERSON of DATE , PERSON can not usefully rely on thischange in the legal position in order to plead that the Minister of the ORG was under a duty to rescind thedeportation order issued against him under previouslegislation concerning aliens . It was exclusively amatter for the Minister to whom an application for suchan order to be rescinded has been made to determinewhether , in accordance with section CARDINAL of the Ordinance of DATE as in force at the date of theapplication , the presence of the person concerned PERSON territory represented a serious threat to public order .

It appears from the documents in the file that the Minister , who took his decision in the light of all theevidence in the case , did not make a manifest error ofassessment in finding that the presence in GPE of theappellant , who had committed repeated and increasingly serious offences , including that of living on theearnings of prostitution with aggravating circumstances , still represented , as at DATE , a serious threatto public order . He was therefore entitled to refuse torescind the order for Mr Boughanemi ’s deportation .

In the circumstances of this case , the Minister of the ORG ’s refusal to rescind the deportation order made against PERSON , who returned to GPE and lived there illegally after the execution of that deportationorder , did not interfere with the latter ’s family life toan extent that exceeded what was necessary to preservepublic order . Thus the submission that the refusal torescind the deportation order of CARDINAL DATE infringed the right to respect for family life guaranteed PERSON ( article CARDINAL) of ORG must fail .
CARDINAL . Mr Boughanemi was arrested on DATE for breach of the deportation order and was sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . On DATE he was deported to GPE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the ORG received from Miss PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) the following letter , dated DATE :
" As partner ( concubine ) and mother of the child ofMr PERSON , I wish by this letter to draw yourattention to our situation .
The difficulty of getting his identity papers back makesit impossible for us to lead a normal life .

There is also the fact that , as I am myself unemployed , my financial circumstances make it impossible for me togive him either moral or financial support . What ismore , I am his partner and , despite all his efforts to berecognised as a normal citizen , it is unfortunately impossible for us to live together . Faced with all the problems raised by his getting administrative recognition , I write to you in the hope that you willtake account of the fact that both he and I are acting ingood faith .
On DATE Miss PERSON made the following statement to an officer of the criminal investigation department ( extracts from the police report ) :
I do know ORG . I ’ve known him for DATE . I lived with him from DATE till DATE when we separated because of a disagreement .
When we lived together he was out of work . He lived at my place ... I paid for his keep .
He never gave me any money because he did n’t have any .
He did n’t recognise my son until DATE , because tobegin with I was n’t too keen on the idea .
So far he has never sent any money for our child . PERSON me from time to time to find out if there is anynews about his application to ORG . I do n’t intend to live with him if he comes back .
I have nothing else to say on this matter .

The PERSON of DATE restored the wording that this section had contained prior to the PERSON of DATE , to the effect that deportation might only be ordered in the event of a " serious " threat to public order .
